content: How can I help you today?

I've just been so stressed out lately, mainly with work. I can’t stop thinking about the possibility of getting fired, and it’s keeping me up all night. I feel like I can’t shut my brain off, and it’s just been exhausting. My partner thought talking to you might help, but honestly, I’m not sure.

That sounds incredibly overwhelming, dealing with those thoughts and the exhaustion of sleepless nights. It’s understandable how this could feel like a heavy weight, especially with work stress piling on. Thank you for sharing this—it’s a lot to carry. If you don’t mind, what’s been most difficult for you about this situation?

I guess the hardest part is not knowing what's going to happen. I’ve been overthinking everything—if they're going to do layoffs, if there's something specific I’ve done wrong, or if I’ll even be able to find another job quickly if it happens. I feel like I’m failing my family by not having it all under control. It's just… a lot to handle all at once.

Not knowing what's ahead can make everything feel so uncertain, and on top of that, you’re putting this pressure on yourself to be strong for your family. It sounds like you’re carrying a difficult mix of fear, responsibility, and self-criticism, all at the same time. How are you managing to get through each day with all of this weighing on you?

I’m just taking it one step at a time, but honestly, it feels like I’m barely holding it together. I go through the motions at work and try to act like everything’s fine, but inside, I’m constantly worrying. By the time I get home, I feel drained, but I want to be there for my partner and kids, so I push through. It’s exhausting, though.

It sounds like you’re working really hard to keep going, even when you’re feeling drained and weighed down by worry. Balancing the effort to stay strong for your family while dealing with the stress at work must be tough, and it takes a lot of strength to push through like you’ve been doing. What keeps you motivated to keep going despite all the exhaustion?

I guess it’s my family—my kids, especially. I want to give them a stable and happy life, and I don’t want them to see me falling apart. My partner is already worried about me, and I don’t want to add more stress. I feel like I have to keep it together for them, even when I feel like I’m barely able to myself.

Your dedication to your family really shines through—it’s clear how much you care about giving them the stability and happiness they deserve. At the same time, you’re carrying so much of this on your own, not wanting to burden anyone, even when it’s been really hard for you. How do you feel about the balance between taking care of your family and finding ways to care for yourself?

I guess I don’t really feel like I have much time or space to take care of myself. It’s like I have to put everyone else first, and whatever is left over is for me—if there’s anything left at all. I don’t even know where I’d start if I tried to focus on myself more. It feels selfish to even think about it sometimes.

It sounds like you’ve been prioritizing everyone else’s needs, often leaving little or none of that energy for yourself. Feeling like focusing on yourself might be selfish can make it even harder to take those steps. Still, what you’ve shared shows how much you care for others, and it might be worth exploring how taking care of yourself could actually help you continue being there for them. What would taking care of yourself—even in small ways—look like, if it felt okay to try?

It sounds like you’ve been prioritizing everyone else’s needs, often leaving little or none of that energy for yourself. Feeling like focusing on yourself might be selfish can make it even harder to take those steps. Still, what you’ve shared shows how much you care for others, and it might be worth exploring how taking care of yourself could actually help you continue being there for them. What would taking care of yourself—even in small ways—look like, if it felt okay to try?

It’s understandable that figuring out where to begin can feel daunting. You’ve been so focused on the needs of your family, and imagining ways to shift even a little attention toward yourself might feel unfamiliar at first. Would you be open to exploring what small steps, even the simplest ones, might help you feel less drained or give you a moment of relief from the stress?

I guess maybe taking a short walk or stepping away from everything for a few minutes could help. Or even just sitting quietly by myself without distractions might make a difference. I don’t know if it would fix anything, but it could give me a break from everything rushing through my head.

Those sound like thoughtful ideas—taking a walk or setting aside quiet time for yourself could give you a moment to breathe amidst all the stress. Even if it doesn’t fix everything, it could offer you a small relief or a bit of space to recharge. What would make it feel okay to try out something like this in your daily routine?

I guess just finding the time to actually do it would help. My days feel so packed—between work, taking care of the kids, and trying to keep up with everything—I don’t know where I would fit it in. Maybe if I did it after the kids go to bed or first thing in the morning, but I’d probably feel guilty taking that time for myself.

Balancing your packed days and carving out time for yourself sounds challenging, especially when guilt comes into the picture. It might help to think of it not as taking time away from your family but as a way to refill your energy so you can keep being there for them. Starting small—like a brief moment after the kids are in bed or in the morning—might be a gentle way to test this out without feeling like you’re taking too much time. What do you think about easing into it like that?

Finding time for yourself when your schedule is already so full is definitely tough, and I can understand why you might feel guilty about it. But maybe it would help to think of this time as something that could benefit your family too—when you take care of yourself, you’re able to show up for them with more energy and patience. Would starting with just 5 or 10 minutes in the morning or evening feel more manageable?

Easing into it with just 5 or 10 minutes could be a good start. That way, it doesn’t feel like too big of a step, and it might begin to fit more naturally into your day over time. How would it feel to try something like that—even just once—to see what comes of it?

Easing into it with just 5 or 10 minutes sounds doable. I think I could try that, just to see if it helps even a little. Maybe I'll start with sitting quietly after the kids are in bed and see how it feels. I guess it’s worth a try.

That sounds like a thoughtful step, and it’s great to hear you’re open to giving it a try. Sitting quietly after the kids are in bed could give you a chance to decompress and settle your thoughts, even if it’s just for a few minutes. Would you like to talk more about how you could build this time for yourself, or is there something else on your mind that you'd like to explore?
